title: Jesus' Ministry and Miracles
shortSummary: Mark chapter 6 highlights Jesus’ rejection in His hometown, the sending out of the twelve apostles, the beheading of John the Baptist, and several miracles including the feeding of the five thousand and Jesus walking on water. This chapter reveals both human unbelief and divine compassion, emphasizing Jesus’ authority and care for the people.
timeline: c. AD 27-29 - Early Ministry of Jesus

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God and central figure of the chapter, teaching, performing miracles, and sending out His disciples.

keyCharacters.name: John the Baptist
keyCharacters.description: The forerunner of Christ who was imprisoned and beheaded by Herod, his death marking a significant event in the narrative.

keyCharacters.name: Herod Antipas
keyCharacters.description: The ruler who imprisoned John the Baptist and ordered his execution at the request of Herodias' daughter.

keyCharacters.name: The Twelve Apostles
keyCharacters.description: Jesus’ chosen disciples sent out in pairs to preach, heal, and cast out demons, demonstrating the extension of Jesus’ ministry.

definitions.definition: The seventh day of the week, observed by Jews as a day of rest and worship, significant in Jesus’ teaching in the synagogue.
Demons or evil spirits from which Jesus gave His disciples authority to cast out, demonstrating spiritual power.
A large flat dish or platter used to carry food or, in this chapter, the head of John the Baptist.

definitions.term: The fourth watch of the night
definitions.definition: A time division in the night, roughly between 3:00 and 6:00 AM, when Jesus walked on the sea to His disciples.

outline.heading: Jesus Rejected at Nazareth
outline.description: Jesus returns to His hometown where He faces unbelief and rejection despite His wisdom and miracles, illustrating the difficulty of acceptance among those familiar with Him.

outline.heading: Sending Out the Twelve Apostles
outline.description: Jesus empowers and commissions His twelve disciples to preach repentance, heal the sick, and cast out demons, emphasizing dependence on God and the urgency of the gospel.

outline.heading: The Death of John the Baptist
outline.description: The chapter recounts the imprisonment and beheading of John the Baptist by Herod, highlighting the cost of prophetic witness and the fulfillment of God’s plan.

outline.heading: Jesus Feeds the Five Thousand
outline.description: Jesus miraculously feeds a large crowd with five loaves and two fishes, demonstrating His compassion and divine provision.

outline.heading: Jesus Walks on Water
outline.description: Jesus walks on the sea to His struggling disciples, revealing His authority over nature and encouraging faith despite fear and doubt.

outline.heading: Healing in Gennesaret
outline.description: Jesus heals many who touch the border of His garment, showing His power to heal and the faith of the people who sought Him.

application: Trust God’s timing and plan even when your efforts seem rejected or unrecognized, as Jesus experienced rejection in His own hometown.
Obey Jesus’ commands to share the gospel and minister to others, relying on His power rather than your own resources.
Stand firm in righteousness and truth, like John the Baptist, even when facing opposition or persecution.
Have faith in Jesus’ provision and power in times of need, remembering His miracles of feeding and calming the storm.

keyVerses.text: But Jesus said unto them, A prophet is not without honour, but in his own country, and among his own kin, and in his own house.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the challenge of unbelief and rejection even toward those closest to us, emphasizing the cost of prophetic ministry.

keyVerses.text: And when he had taken the five loaves and the two fishes, he looked up to heaven, and blessed, and brake the loaves, and gave them to his disciples to set before them; and the two fishes divided he among them all.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Jesus’ divine provision and the power of blessing, central to the miracle of feeding the five thousand.

keyVerses.text: For they all saw him, and were troubled. And immediately he talked with them, and saith unto them, Be of good cheer: it is I; be not afraid.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus’ reassurance to His disciples reveals His presence as the source of peace and courage amid fear and trials.

keyVerses.text: And whithersoever he entered, into villages, or cities, or country, they laid the sick in the streets, and besought him that they might touch if it were but the border of his garment: and as many as touched him were made whole.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates the power of faith and Jesus’ ability to heal, encouraging believers to seek Him earnestly.
